subject: Junit Version4.0
msgSnippet:
Hi,
Any ideas when is the jnit version 4.0 is to be released.
Further ,has anyone used anotations feature of jdk1.5.
Can anybody guide me about it
 Anjali
messageBody:
Hi,
Any ideas when is the jnit version 4.0 is to be released.
Further ,has anyone used anotations feature of jdk1.5.
Can anybody guide me about it
> Anjali Jain

Message: 1
Date: Fri, 24 Jun 2005 12:24:17 -0000
From: "arnabgupta2000" <arnabgupta2000@...>
Subject: Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters

Hello,

I am new to JUnit and in need for a solution. I have written a
library
of which I need to test one class. The methods exposed by this class
cannot be called randomly but by following some rules. For example,
there is a method "Connect" which must be invoked before any other
method is called. There are additional calls that are related. For
example "ChangeHeaders" makes temporary change to some data (after
some business logic verification), however this must be followed by a
call to "SaveChanges" to persist this data. Whatever I have read
about
JUnit seems to indicate that the test methods in my test class can be
called in any order by the JUnit framework. Is there any way (a
pattern) to get around this issue ? Thanks much in advance..

Regards,
Arnab.






________________________________________________________________________
________________________________________________________________________

Message: 2
Date: Thu, 23 Jun 2005 15:46:02 -0700
From: Michael Giroux <mlgiroux@...>
Subject: JUNITREPORT ANT Task Suggestion

Not sure if this is the correct place to post this, let me know if I
shouold post to Apache ANT list.

The ANT JunitReport task includes all properties that were defined at
the time of the test. If any of these properties contain security
information (userid, password, ...) that was needed for any part of
the overall build, these values become public information when the
JunitReport is published.

Suggestion:
JunitReport should take a nested element, perhaps regular expressions,
that allow the developer to filter/remove individual properties so
they do not appear in the generated HTML documents.

Current Avoidance:
I'm using <replaceregexp> ANT task to modify the input xml files for now.

Michael Giroux




________________________________________________________________________
________________________________________________________________________

Message: 3
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 00:21:03 -0000
From: "raycclough" <ray@...>
Subject: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Singleton

I know that the JUnit community frowns on Singletons. However I have
a piece of code which uses a singleton, and I want to test it. The
singleton takes a "Reader" in it's constructor (which may be null, and
then it uses a properties file to create its data). I want to test it
using various different data sets. In line with that, I created a
custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to create the object. It
works great (except, of course, where it doesn't). The reflexively
obtained constructor returns an object of type 'Object', which the
debugger says has the correct underlying type, and it contains the
correct data, but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be. Any
hint to what I'm doing wrong? Thanks for any advice you can give me
on this.

Here's the relevant code from the JUnit 'setUp()' method:

//////// start code
try {
// since the Controller is a singleton, and may have been loaded
// before with different set-up data, use a ClassLoader to
// create a new instance of it. This requires using Java
// Reflection to instantiate the object. If we just called
// "classForName()", the system class loader would be asked to
// return any previously loaded instance of the class. Since
// this is what we want to avoid, a special ClassLoader returns
// a new instance of the class.
SpecialClassLoader loader = new SpecialClassLoader();
Class ctlrClass = loader.findClass(
"rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.DefaultGatewayController");

// instantiate the controller using reflection
Class[] paramTypes = { Reader.class };
Object[] args = {reader}; // contains the "test data"

Constructor constructor =
ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
constructor.setAccessible(true);
Object o = constructor.newInstance(args);

//Method m = ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
//m.setAccessible(true);
//Object o = m.invoke(null,args);

// TODO - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
// unfortunately somehow the Object may not be cast to the required
// class "DefaultGatewayController", or even to its interface.
// This is true whether the "Constructor" method or the "Method"
// method is used.

if ( DefaultGatewayController.class.isInstance(o) ) {
// "o" may safely be cast as a "DefaultGatewayController"
System.out.println("YOWSA");
ctlr = (DefaultGatewayController)o;
} else {
System.out.println("OHNO");
System.out.println("Class: " + o.getClass().getName());
}

} catch (ClassNotFoundException cnfe) {
cnfe.printStackTrace();
} catch (NoSuchMethodException nsme) {
nsme.printStackTrace();
} catch (IllegalAccessException iae) {
iae.printStackTrace();
} catch (InvocationTargetException ite) {
ite.printStackTrace();
} catch (InstantiationException ie) {
ie.printStackTrace();
} catch (ClassCastException cce) {
cce.printStackTrace();
}

//////// end code

This always goes thru the "OHNO" branch, although the output of the
class name is what it should be to allow me to cast it. I'm fairly
new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Class Loaders, but it seems
to me that this should work easily and well. Thanks,
- Ray Clough
ray@...






________________________________________________________________________
________________________________________________________________________

Message: 4
Date: Mon, 27 Jun 2005 19:17:03 -0000
From: "nayoo1979" <nayoo1979@...>
Subject: JUnit in Net Beans

Hi

I am a complete newbie in JUnit and today is my first day learning
it. Please bear with me if my question is too dumb.

I am using Net Beans IDE 4.1. From that, I am trying to build codes
from http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/testinfected/testing.htm

The problem is that NetBeans does not understand TestCase in

public class MoneyTest extends TestCase {

so I added

import junit.framework.*;

Still, it is giving me error as below:

D:\MyJava\CurrencyTestJunit\src\currencytestjunit\MoneyTest.java:13:
package junit.framework does not exist
import junit.framework.*;
D:\MyJava\CurrencyTestJunit\src\currencytestjunit\MoneyTest.java:24:
cannot resolve symbol
symbol : class TestCase
location: class currencytestjunit.MoneyTest
public class MoneyTest extends TestCase{


Why can't I import junit from NetBean?
I am also quite new in Java and beginner level. Please help me if you
know the answer.

Thank you.

Message: 6
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 09:35:52 +0200
From: Neil Swingler <neil@...>
Subject: Re: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Singleton




> I know that the JUnit community frowns on Singletons. However I have
> a piece of code which uses a singleton, and I want to test it. The
> singleton takes a "Reader" in it's constructor (which may be null, and
> then it uses a properties file to create its data). I want to test it
> using various different data sets. In line with that, I created a
> custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to create the object. It
> works great (except, of course, where it doesn't). The reflexively
> obtained constructor returns an object of type 'Object', which the
> debugger says has the correct underlying type, and it contains the
> correct data, but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be. Any
> hint to what I'm doing wrong? Thanks for any advice you can give me
> on this.
>
> Here's the relevant code from the JUnit 'setUp()' method:
>
> //////// start code
> try {

> // since the Controller is a singleton, and may have been loaded
> // before with different set-up data, use a ClassLoader to
> // create a new instance of it. This requires using Java
> // Reflection to instantiate the object. If we just called
> // "classForName()", the system class loader would be asked to
> // return any previously loaded instance of the class. Since
> // this is what we want to avoid, a special ClassLoader returns
> // a new instance of the class.
> SpecialClassLoader loader = new SpecialClassLoader();
> Class ctlrClass = loader.findClass(
> "rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.DefaultGatewayController");
>
> // instantiate the controller using reflection
> Class[] paramTypes = { Reader.class };
> Object[] args = {reader}; // contains the "test data"
>
> Constructor constructor =
> ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
> constructor.setAccessible(true);
> Object o = constructor.newInstance(args);

If you are going to use reflection to defeat the private constructor, why bother reloading the class.

>
> //Method m = ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
> //m.setAccessible(true);
> //Object o = m.invoke(null,args);
>
> // TODO - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> // unfortunately somehow the Object may not be cast to the required
> // class "DefaultGatewayController", or even to its interface.
> // This is true whether the "Constructor" method or the "Method"
> // method is used.
>
> if ( DefaultGatewayController.class.isInstance(o) ) {
> // "o" may safely be cast as a "DefaultGatewayController"
> System.out.println("YOWSA");
> ctlr = (DefaultGatewayController)o;

The problem is that "DefaultGatewayController.class" is not the same instance as ctlrClass. Although if DefaultGatewayController had an interface I would expect you to be able to cast it to that.

> } else {
> System.out.println("OHNO");
> System.out.println("Class: " + o.getClass().getName());
> }
>

snipped exception handling - why not just declare the test as throws Exception.

> This always goes thru the "OHNO" branch, although the output of the
> class name is what it should be to allow me to cast it. I'm fairly
> new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Class Loaders, but it seems
> to me that this should work easily and well. Thanks,
> - Ray Clough
> ray@...
>

There are 2 solutions:
1) load the entire junit test using your special classloader. This is not easy.

2) Invoke the methods on ctlr using reflection.

In the files section I submitted an example of a classreloader. JB Rainsberger's JUnit Recipes also contains a recipe on this subject.

I have since come up with a much simpler version of the reloader that you can find in my JIsolate project:
http://sourceforge.net/projects/jisolate

No release avaliable yet but if you pull the project from cvs into eclipse you may get some ideas.

- Neil


________________________________________________________________________
________________________________________________________________________

Message: 7
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 09:52:50 +0100
From: Chris Dollin <kers@...>
Subject: Re: Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters

On Friday 24 June 2005 13:24, arnabgupta2000 wrote:
> Hello,
>
> I am new to JUnit and in need for a solution. I have written a
> library
> of which I need to test one class. The methods exposed by this class
> cannot be called randomly but by following some rules. For example,
> there is a method "Connect" which must be invoked before any other
> method is called. There are additional calls that are related. For
> example "ChangeHeaders" makes temporary change to some data (after
> some business logic verification), however this must be followed by a
> call to "SaveChanges" to persist this data. Whatever I have read
> about
> JUnit seems to indicate that the test methods in my test class can be
> called in any order by the JUnit framework. Is there any way (a
> pattern) to get around this issue ? Thanks much in advance..

Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessarily) called
in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test method should
be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's too hard to eg move
them around for greater expressivity, call only the failing when
when you want to isolate a problem, &co.

There are at least two things you can do:

(a) Ensure that each test uses its own object (easy) and that it
runs the piece of lifecycle you're interested in to
completion.

(b) Refactor so that this object-state dependency is reduced
(preferably to zero).

For (b) I'd start by fixing the `connect` problem: if nothing
can be done withotu a connection, I'd have a more factory-like
object with a `connect` method; calling this delivers a connected
object.

For Change/Save, I'd just have the test do the Change and then
the Save in the same testXXX() method.

--
Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.



________________________________________________________________________
________________________________________________________________________

Message: 8
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 10:00:37 +0100
From: Andrew McDonagh <andrew.mcdonagh@...>
Subject: Re: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Singleton

raycclough wrote:

>I know that the JUnit community frowns on Singletons. However I have
>a piece of code which uses a singleton, and I want to test it. The
>singleton takes a "Reader" in it's constructor (which may be null, and
>then it uses a properties file to create its data). I want to test it
>using various different data sets. In line with that, I created a
>custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to create the object. It
>works great (except, of course, where it doesn't). The reflexively
>obtained constructor returns an object of type 'Object', which the
>debugger says has the correct underlying type, and it contains the
>correct data, but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be. Any
>hint to what I'm doing wrong? Thanks for any advice you can give me
>on this.
>
>
>

snipped code.

I take it you want to do some kind of reset of the singleton so that you
can test different datasets?

If so, forget about classloading, reflection, etc and keep it simple.

A number of options are available all...

1) just add a public instance method to reset the reader and anything
else of the singleton:

class DefaultGatewayController {
public static DefaultGatewayController getInstance() {
return s_instance;
}

public void resetReader(Reader r) {
....

}
}

2) Hide the reset methods behind an interface. Move the Singleton
implementation behind an interface and a test interface. The
getInstance() method return type would be the standard interface, but
your tests can cast to the testInterface to get access to the reset methods.

class GatewayControllerSingleton {
private static GatewayController s_instance;

public static GatewayController getInstance() {
if (s_instance != null) {
s_instance = new DefaultGatewayController();
}

return s_instance;
}

}

interface GatewayController {
...
}


interface TestableGatewayController {
void resetReader(Reader r);
}


class DefaultGatewayController implements GatewayController,
TestableGatewayController{
...
}

Plus some other approaches....

HTH

Andrew

Message: 9
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 11:32:38 +0200 (MEST)
From: "Harald Mueller" <harald.m.mueller@...>
Subject: quite OT: Building a system test group

Hi all -

forgive me for this OT posting - but I hope that you can shed light on that
topic; and/or send me to a more appropriate community. Thx!
(I asked on softwaretestingexperts@yahoogroups, but this is more sort of a
job listing group).

---------

I am in an company with about 50 developers (+ management) which now
wants/has to set up a system test group = probably 10..15 people who do
system testing (we have 10 "country versions" of our software and up to 3
versions per country in the field, up to 3 versions "in the making").
I do know about

* testing from a testers perspective (my favorite book: B.Beizer's "Black
Box Testing")

* testing in the developer community (JUnit testing is done, although
haphazardly, by about 50% of the developers; direct application tests are
done by many developers)

but I do NOT know much about "higher level issues" like

* input quality level for system tests done by the system test group (how to
define and ascertain it?)
* management of the system test group
* conflict resolution between development and system test group
* and what else?

Is there any literature out there (books, on the net, ...) that could be
helpful? (yes, I did a google, but up to now the results are "quite mixed").

Also, anyone who has experience to share is very welcome!

Thank you!
Harald M. Mueller
Germany


--

Message: 10
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 12:42:04 -0000
From: "Jeff Grigg" <jeffgrigg@...>
Subject: Re: Using a Special Class Loader to test a Singleton

--- "raycclough" <ray@a...> wrote:
> [...], I created a custom Class Loader, and use Reflection to
> create the object. It works great (except, of course, where
> it doesn't). The reflexively obtained constructor returns an
> object of type 'Object', which the debugger says has the
> correct underlying type, and it contains the correct data,
> but I cannot Cast it to the type it needs to be. Any hint
> to what I'm doing wrong? Thanks for any advice you can give
> me on this.

To directly answer your question: You can't cast the object because
it was created under a different class loader. You can only
interact with that class through reflection. You can't cast it to
types or interfaces -- unless those classes were loaded by a common
class loader -- IE: the system class loader.

I worked around this recently by loading the TestCase class itself
under the new class loader and calling the current test method on
the new instance, using reflection. (And setting a flag so that the
new instance knew it was running under the new class loader.)

A bit more detail: The "type" of an instance, its identification,
is the class name *PLUS* the the address of the ClassLoader instance
that loaded it. That's how web servers keep applications separate
from each other: They create one ClassLoader instance for each
logical application "process" they want to keep separate.

Question:
Since you're already using '.setAccessible(true)' already, why not
use reflection to replace the static singleton instance field?

> [...]
> SpecialClassLoader loader = new SpecialClassLoader();
> Class ctlrClass = loader.findClass(
> "rdyne_rdcs.comm_gateway.controller.DefaultGatewayController");
>
> // instantiate the controller using reflection
> Class[] paramTypes = { Reader.class };
> Object[] args = {reader}; // contains the "test data"
>
> Constructor constructor =
> ctlrClass.getDeclaredConstructor(paramTypes);
> constructor.setAccessible(true);
> Object o = constructor.newInstance(args);
>
> //Method m = ctlrClass.getMethod("getController",paramTypes);
> //m.setAccessible(true);
> //Object o = m.invoke(null,args);
>
> // TODO - Figure this out!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
> // unfortunately somehow the Object may not be cast to the required
> // class "DefaultGatewayController", or even to its interface.
> // This is true whether the "Constructor" method or the "Method"
> // method is used.
>
> if ( DefaultGatewayController.class.isInstance(o) ) {
> // "o" may safely be cast as a "DefaultGatewayController"
> System.out.println("YOWSA");
> ctlr = (DefaultGatewayController)o;
> } else {
> System.out.println("OHNO");
> System.out.println("Class: " + o.getClass().getName());
> }
> [...]
>
> This always goes thru the "OHNO" branch, although the output
> of the class name is what it should be to allow me to cast it.
> I'm fairly new to JUnit, and I'm really new to custom Class
> Loaders, but it seems to me that this should work easily and
> well. [...]

Message: 11
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 07:50:42 -0600
From: "Bradley, Todd" <todd.bradley@...>
Subject: RE: quite OT: Building a system test group

I've been a software test manager for about 5 of the past 10 years, and
learned much of what I know from reading "STQE" magazine, now called
"Better Software". If you can get a subscription to that in Germany,
I'd recommend it. They also have a lot of good system testing content
on their website: http://stickyminds.com

Finally, don't underestimate the benefit of hiring a consulting for a
month or two to help jump start your system test program. I'd recommend
that the consultant should be me and that the month or two should
include Oktoberfest. (just kidding)


Todd.

Message: 12
Date: Tue, 28 Jun 2005 06:56:06 -0700
From: "Cedric Beust" <cbeust@...>
Subject: RE: Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters

> From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On
> Behalf Of Chris Dollin

> Yes, the methods in your test class are not (necessarily)
> called in any particular order. This is a feature. Each test
> method should be unrelated to the others - otherwise it's too
> hard to eg move them around for greater expressivity, call
> only the failing when when you want to isolate a problem, &co.

I don't see why it's too hard to do that: the framework will always
guarantee that the methods are invoked in the right order and that dependent
methods will always be invoked before.

Anyway, the short answer to the original question is that ordering testing
methods is not covered by unit testing, and if you want to do this, you are
probably doing more than unit testing (and you should therefore use
http://testng.org :-)).

> For (b) I'd start by fixing the `connect` problem: if nothing
> can be done withotu a connection, I'd have a more
> factory-like object with a `connect` method; calling this
> delivers a connected object.

If this object is expensive to get, it would be nice to save it in-between
invocations, which brings us back to maintaining state and ordering methods.

--
CÃ©dric
http://beust.com/weblog

Jim

Subject: Re: Testing API where order in which methods are invoked matters

> If this object is expensive to get, it would be nice to save it in-between

and work out how to carve out the expensive bits and not use them when
unnecessary.

Chris "electric hedgehog" Dollin
It's called *extreme* programming, not *stupid* programming.
